title: Will the US Truck Tonnage Index reach or exceed 120.0 before 1 January 2022?
preds:
EDIT:
Likely too late for the purposes of this question...
https://www.whitehouse.gov/briefing-room/statements-releases/2021/12/16/fact-sheet-the-biden-%e2%81%a0harris-administration-trucking-action-plan-to-strengthen-americas-trucking-workforce/
No. Volatility is low hence value will be close to current
Unlikely given where it was in Ocotber, but it clearly is increasing and there are plenty of opprotunites for increase with the recent efforts at reducing port congestion
A shortage of truck drivers is a major problem
only exceeded 120 once before in pre covid environment. unlikely to break through in near term due to supply shortages , driver shortages,  covid lockdowns &c.

113 in October. Moving in the right direction but probably not enough to crack 120 this year. a 7 pt jump would be a feat https://www.truckinginfo.com/10156718/ata-truck-tonnage-index-increased-in-october
The US Truck Tonnage Index only ever exceeded 120 once. Moreover, large movements seem infrequent.

Slightly increasing forecast for now on continued demand for trucking services plus the fairly large 2.4-point monthly increase in the BTS tonnage index reported for September. Unlikely there is enough time left to reach 120.0 on the index by year-end. September's 2.4 increase would need to (essentially) be replicated each remaining month to exceed 120. FWIW: The BTS seasonally-adjusted index did not rise dramatically (e.g., more than two index 'points') during the final months of 2015, 2016, '17, '18 or 2019. (2020 a pandemic year..no large rise at the end of that year, either.) https://data.bts.gov/Research-and-Statistics/Truck-Tonnage-Seasonally-Adjusted-Index-/6hvx-3geb https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/ata-truck-tonnage-index-increased-2-4-in-september-301403771.html

"For-Hire Truck Tonnage Index increased 2.4% in September; 'It is good that tonnage rose in September, but it is important to note that this is happening because each truck is hauling more, not from an increase in the amount of equipment operated as contract carriers in the for-hire truckload market continue to shrink from the lack of new trucks and drivers.' " https://www.trucking.org/news-insights/ata-truck-tonnage-index-increased-24-september BTS number isn't out yet but should be similar (I think...). With 3 months left to report a ~7% jump is unlikely but not impossible with the govt. getting involved in pushing more port traffic, especially in the LA area, and the rush for early Christmas buying starting due to supply issues. I still don't think it's going to happen but feel 6% odds is too low so am coming up slightly.

Slight uptick in a different truck tonnage index for August, but supply chain issues and driver shortages remain: https://www.ccjdigital.com/business/article/15114958/ata-truck-tonnage-up-for-first-time-since-march
My optimism is dropping as the port congestion seems to be going nowhere and now that China is slowing production on top of domestic issues it's not looking likely

Index history has dropped to 112 for August from 113. The trend is down. Supply chains are disrupted, auto sales are down, container traffic is down general goods stable. Covid spread in the US Mid-west is rampant and deaths continue (temporary morgue truck traffic is up….). Economy likely to improve this year into next. Forecast Truck Tonnage index:113.0
mark to market, delta & supply bottlenecks lead to reduced estimate

July = 110.6; 2021 average (112.53) flat over 2019 (112.93) Jab mandate threatening increased driver shortage? https://theloadstar.com/us-trucking-industry-could-struggle-with-new-covid-vaccination-requirements/ Holding at 0%

If anyone is looking for the new index page, it seems to have been moved here (link in the question now leads elsewhere): https://data.bts.gov/Research-and-Statistics/Truck-Tonnage-Seasonally-Adjusted-Index-/6hvx-3geb ; I have requested a clarification. (still no data on July, at the time of writing)
Seems rather unlikely but just maybe there's a whole lot of freightin' somewhere to get caught up on.
Lowering probability based on recent posts from @jayb, @DBCooper, and @jflom.
Amazon has waived drug testing to hire drivers. Those would be Intra State drivers however who are exempt from Federal Rules.
Currently a "capacity crisis", plus supply chain issues: https://www.logisticsmgmt.com/article/truck_tonnage_sees_july_decreases_reports_ata

Capacity not demand issue. OEM class 8 production cut this week, shipper pricing survey indicates accelerating TL rates expectation, supply chains deteriorating thru Aug. Rail Service recovery = intermodal takes share during peak season.

https://www.logisticsmgmt.com/article/truck_tonnage_sees_july_decreases_reports_ata July preliminary reports showing 109.8 down from 112 in June which was actually downwardly revised as well... currently Monte Carlo below showing a 1.1% chance https://github.com/jmflom/Superforecasting/tree/main/Truck%20Tonnage

Challenges on the supply side - finding qualified drivers.
Overwhelming liklihood is that it won't hit.  Challenge is arriving at the proper probabilities.
From June2020-June2021, average is 112.6.  Std dev (monthly) = 1.06. There was a 2 point jump between June2020 and Dec2020.  If 114 is expected, 116 one sigma deviation, 118 two sigma.  120 three sigma - 99.87%.   Taking a more optimistic view, if 115 is expected (3 point increase) and that is the standard deviation, then we'd be looking at about 90%.  There is a chance trucking could fall of course, so much more weight to the 99%. Interestingly 114.8 was reported (max since Covid) in Jan2021.  I would've expected the highest truck load to be in December with Xmas.  Might reflect less working days in December, and some backlog (ecommerce returns driving as well). https://www.yardeni.com/pub/atatruck.pdf
https://www.trucking.org/news-insights/latest-freight-forecast-projects-256-increase-tonnage-2030
https://www.trucknews.com/business-management/u-s-truck-tonnage-shrinks-in-april-but-outlook-is-strong/1003151179/
Coming down a bit as it seems like there isn't enough time left to see so much growth in this.
Experts offer stats that make this seem unlikely...https://www.yardeni.com/pub/atatruck.pdf

I think with China closing down 25% of their port capacity due to COVID, there is not enough inbound tonnage to reach 120.0 (unless it is reached within the next 60 days due to tonnage awaiting offloading already or en route).

I felt as though my 9% estimate was too high so I pulled data from the BTS API, pulled from a normal distribution of both 1 month % gains and 6 month % gains. Then using random walks for the 1month and simple multiplication for the 6 month got the following percentages from Monte Carlo estimation Six Month Rolling Prob.: 0.001% 
One Month Rolling Prob.: 3.893% See code here (https://github.com/jmflom/Superforecasting/blob/main/Truck%20Tonnage/truck_tonnage.py)
-10, June number went down, no sign of a rise yet.

The index for June 2021 came down to 112. 
Simply looking at the graph, I see that the there was never a jump of anything close to 8 points in time span of 6 months (we have only 5 months left). Be it lack of drivers, supply chain issues, or the economy progressing not fast enough, I don't see the index reach 120 (and we have to remember that it only reached 120 in August 2019 once | July 2019 was 118.4 | and September 2019 was 117.6) # =============
"Supply chain issues are likely putting some downward pressure on tonnage," "But it is also likely that tonnage isn't growing as much as it could because of industry-specific supply constraints. This index is dominated by contract freight, and the for-hire truckload carriers have seen their tractor counts fall because they are having difficulty finding qualified drivers. It is difficult to move more tonnage with less equipment, which is why we are seeing strong volumes in the spot market as shippers scramble to get loads moved."
https://www.truckinginfo.com/10147672/supply-chain-driver-shortage-issues-affect-truck-tonnage  [20 July, 2021]
# ============ => My estimate would be somewhere around 115.5
Kind of like the levels it was at the end of 2018 [from June to November  time period]

=> I think I'm comfortable enough to make my final forecast.

Decreased 1.5% in June after falling 1% in May, flattening trend
https://www.fleetowner.com/news/economics/article/21170301/ata-truck-tonnage-is-flattening-remains-above-2020-levels

I'm still of the opinion that there's a massive backlog of inventory that needs to be moved and the issue is with lack of drivers. I'm coming down a bit as recruitment may still lag but the potential seems to be there. "The railroads are full. The warehouses are full. Port terminals are full. Ships are coming in and waiting to get worked. The factories are behind in orders. This incredible demand has got everybody in the entire value chain just clipping out at levels we never could have imagined — and it’s still not enough. We’ve still got so much cargo coming in. We were on the phone with a big retailer this morning and they said that they’re still going to need another year to get inventories up to a level they think is appropriate." 
"On the trucking side, we’ve got about 18,000 truckers registered individually to do business at this port, only half of which call at the port at least once a week. With these terminals super-full with containers, that slows down truck times. Because we’re not getting four turns a day, we’re only getting two, we need more drivers and you still have half the population you can recruit into this business. How quickly individual companies and independent contractors want to [resume work at the port] remains the question."
https://www.freightwaves.com/news/in-the-eye-of-the-congestion-storm-qa-with-port-of-las-gene-seroka
New figure came out - down to 112.  Going the wrong direction.
June tonnage (112) down from May (113.4).  Holding at 0% chance.
-5 on a decline in June according to this: https://www.yardeni.com/pub/atatruck.pdf
Lowering odds given spread of delta variant that could curb economic activity in 2H due to consumer hesitancy

A rise in the index is generally seen as a rise in the economy, because it indicates that production is up, as well as of consumption of consumer goods.
https://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/truck-tonnage-index.asp Now the index is at 113.8 (as of May 2021). Although the US economy is recovering, I don't think it could justify a +6 point increase. Especially with the uncertainties around delta variant and those hesitant to get vaccinated.  crowd forecast was 19% at this point.

"American Trucking Associations' advanced seasonally adjusted (SA) For-Hire Truck Tonnage Index decreased 1.5% in June after falling 1% in May." 
Source: https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/ata-truck-tonnage-index-decreased-1-5-in-june-301337664.html Additional excerpt/quotation: "Supply chain issues are likely putting some downward pressure on tonnage....But it is also likely that tonnage isn't growing as much as it could because of industry-specific supply constraints. This index is dominated by contract freight, and the for-hire truckload carriers have seen their tractor counts fall because they are having difficulty finding qualified drivers. It is difficult to move more tonnage with less equipment, which is why we are seeing strong volumes in the spot market as shippers scramble to get loads moved." Perhaps despite the current conditions described above, slightly raising forecast for now based upon several forecasters' observations, below

Railroads have begun traffic throttling the east and west coast container ports because the intermodal hubs are stuffed. Truckers are being given exceptions to rules about hours  of operation. Wildcat Truckers are resurgent as more and more buy their own rigs. Unless we federalize interstate trucking again.

Really valuable question for me since it required doing a recursive function to check every month and required refactoring into multiple function chains, which revealed a few small bugs in my code. Anyway, since it is hitting it at any time over the period, this is higher than people suspect.
Volume predictions toward end 2021 look strong https://www.truckinginfo.com/10132428/ftr-2021-freight-volume-rates-look-strong-but-risks-remain

Reducing the probability from 13 to 12% based on release of May data.  From April to May, the data changed form 113.5 to 113.8, which is relatively small.  The data is not on track to reach 120.0 without a very strong acceleration in trucking activity.

May update for the question's data source adds to mostly flat growth in the index over the past few months. (https://www.transtats.bts.gov/osea/seasonaladjustment/?PageVar=TRUCK). Assuming basic comparability, May's seasonally-adjusted index value is fairly close to December 2020's number.  As noted in other comments robust growth will be needed to reach 120.0 by year's end. Increasing U.S. COVID cases could be one negative factor (for robust growth), going forward: https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-s-covid-19-case-counts-have-doubled-in-recent-weeks-11626198501

There might be three scenarios: 
1. Staying on range from 100-115 (current 113+) 
2. Going above range (115-120)
3. Exceding 120 (historic gains) Economic improvements from general economy, which at the end affect possibilities for more truck usage are up, logistics costs are also up (mainly water). Land logistics conditions depend more on human side (labor, working conditions). The downside is that economy growth will not be enought because it is going at a different speed than covid reaction.  Following the prior, i give a 20/50/30 for my scenarios.  SOURCES:
https://data.bts.gov/Research-and-Statistics/Truck-Tonnage-Index-Seasonally-Adjusted/fdsx-2s48
https://www.ccjdigital.com/economic-trends/indicators/article/15066174/truck-tonnage-dipped-for-second-consecutive-month-while-still-strong-yearoveryear

The trucker population is aging and underpaid: likely right wing and unwilling to vaccinate. This could lead to labour shortages. There are likely to be other production bottlenecks as the economy opens quickly. I expect ongoing ‘ransom ware’ problems with logistics chains - e.g. food, container handling. GDP is likely to be ~6% and index growth is normally 1.6%  this could be stagnant. There is a container shortage, this could affect intermodal and trucking. Presently truck tonnage index 113.8 X 0.9= 102
avg of my initial forecast and @the_trumpet_vine forecast

Let's start with the statistics:  The current value of the report is 113.8.  In order to get to 120 over the next 8-months, there needs to be an increase of 5.45%.  In using data from January 2000 forward and looking at the %-change in data over rolling 8-month periods, a 5.45% increase corresponds to the 92nd percentile.  So the base rate for this analysis is 8%. (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/TRUCKD11) Let's tweak the base rate:
1. The data set is not controlled for economic cycles.  Assuming we are not in for a recession in the next 8-months, the base rate should increase to ~29%.
2. Raise of Freight Cargo (https://www.railwayage.com/freight/class-i/rail-traffic-gains-build-in-2q21/): Lower rate to ~21%
3. Employment Shortage:  Several forecasters have commented on employment mix shift in trucker.  Further, many are getting paying jobs, which is actually causing them to stay home more for family reasons (https://www.cnn.com/2021/05/29/economy/truck-driver-shortage-pay-hikes/index.html).
4. New Trucking Laws:  Apparently in early 2020, a new clearing house went into effect to identify truck drivers that should not be driving, "One factor that has reduced the supply of drivers is a new federal clearinghouse that alerts carriers to drivers who have failed drug tests, DUIs or other substance abuse problems on their records. Some 54,000 drivers have been barred from driving since the clearing house went into effect in early 2020." [see CNN article for the quote]. As a result, I put the probability of reaching or exceeding an index value of 120 at 13%.
No.  Shortage of drivers.  Current pandemic isn't over.  Inflation concerns.  The list goes on.
Poorly written question. DOT standards require mandated OVR stuff

US Truck Tonnage has exceeded 120 a singular time in its history.  Going back 2 years it has reached > 120 only 1 month.  This puts the percentage at 1/24 or ~4%.  I'll lean higher per the crowd forecast and @Ryan-Beck comments on it being a proxy for Real GDP although I'm skeptical, especially with possibility of further concerns due to delta variant.

The graph looks like the "K-shaped recovery" often mentioned and which seems to be the case (on Main Street, not Wall St.). Charts aside, it seems like lockdowns and supply chain issues outside of the US will persist for some time to come, and it's been pointed out that many drivers are no longer in the business. Many will probably return to work as extra unemployment benefits fall off, but perhaps not all and perhaps not in trucking.
Hit 113 in April and things continue to pick up. But, notably, the only other time it hit 120 was in August of 2019.

See a fair chance. Will update based on additional data. 
120 over 113.8 (April reading implies a 5.5% increase in the index over an 8 month period which has happened several times in the past (as economy rebounds after a recession).  The index base year is 2015 (which is 100). A 20% increase in a year where you will see pent up demand is not farfetched(on a base year that was 6 years ago)
https://drive.google.com/file/d/11fkpWAdB_VqlpYPINb9QfX10YhywG7ib/view?usp=sharing Reasons for being cautious
1> Sudden unforeseen monetary/fiscal shifts in response to higher than expected inflation
2>  severe 3rd wave(expect low probability even if a 3rd wave happens dont expect lockdowns)

Since the truck tonnage index is used as kind of a proxy for GDP I'm roughly estimating based on GDP projections. The Philadelphia survey of professional forecasters [1] expects real GDP to grow at an annual rate of 7.9% in Q2, 7.5% in Q3, and 5% in Q4. Doing a rough conversion to quarterly rates (dividing by 4) is 1.98% in Q2, 1.87% in Q3, and 1.23% in Q4. The latest trucking numbers are from April, so I'll use that as the starting point. If I'm doing my math right, 113.8*1.0198*1.0187*1.0123 would be 119.7. That's pretty close to 120 and the index can be a bit noisy, so I'm going higher than the crowd as it seems like there's a real possibility it could happen. However I'm still leaning toward it not hitting 120 due to the possibility of driver shortages other users have mentioned. [1]https://www.philadelphiafed.org/surveys-and-data/real-time-data-research/spf-q2-2021

Thanks to the citations by @Scappleby and @jayb , I'm boiling this question down to the following, "The fleets (<100 drivers) who went bankrupt over the past 15 months... will those drivers look for work in the industry once Pandemic Unemployment Assistance benefits end 06SEP?" 150K drivers at small operators stopped working, and only 4K of them found work with big fleets. Either way, I suspect that enough of them will look for work outside of trucking to make hitting 120.0 difficult. 
https://www.ifsmsl.com/2020/12/04/us-truck-driver-shortfall-steeper-than-expected/
the covid peak has passed. currant tonnage will level off
no chance. will continue to drop until the fall of 2023 then rise fast all the way to 2025
i dont believe so. the trend will continue to drop until 2023 then turn around and rise fast.

American Trucking Associations’ advanced seasonally adjusted (SA) For-Hire Truck Tonnage Index increased 1.4% in January after rising 1.2% in December. In January, the index equaled 114.6 (2015=100) compared with 113.1 in December.
Despite a rebounding economy, I believe supple chain shortages, coupled with driver shortages will help keep the index below 120.0.

The BTS trucking tonnage index has exceeded the 120 value in one month over the past 20-plus years but that was fairly recently, in Aug. 2019. The index has generally increased this century, and had risen about 60% from the April 2009 low of 74.8 to the 2019 peak of 120.2 . The index's second-highest point was 118.4 in July 2019. (The April 2021 value was 113.8.) https://www.transtats.bts.gov/osea/seasonaladjustment/?PageVar=TRUCK Good points have been made by other forecasters, especially about ongoing driver shortages. (https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/CES4348400001?amp%253bdata_tool=XGtable&output_view=data&include_graphs=true, https://fredblog.stlouisfed.org/2016/09/planes-trains-automobiles-and-pipelines-and-cargo-ships/). 
..There is also apparently a truck parking shortage: https://talkbusiness.net/2021/06/truck-parking-shortage-worsens-new-study-notes-systems-issues/ Excerpt: "American Trucking Associations' advanced seasonally adjusted (SA) For-Hire Truck Tonnage Index decreased 0.7% in May (2021) after falling 0.6% in April. In May, the index equaled 113.7 (2015=100) compared with 114.5 in April."  However:  "...One freight segment that is helping tonnage is gasoline as demand for travel, both commuting and vacation related, picks up," he said. "I'm also expecting retail freight to remain robust as inventories are at historic lows. As retail stocks are rebuilt, it will boost freight. As has been the case for some time, trucking's biggest challenges are not on the demand side, but on the supply side, including difficulty finding qualified drivers." (https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/ata-truck-tonnage-index-decreased-0-7-in-may-301317548.html) FWIW: Mighty Amazon is reportedly in the process of significantly increasing "...the number of small trucking companies dedicated to hauling goods for Amazon in the U.S..." (https://www.freightwaves.com/news/amazon-logistics-historic-growth-spurt-in-context) A significant, widespread COVID resurgence in the U.S. would be a possible 'wildcard' for this question, but is currently not anticipated. (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/science/forecasting/forecasting-us.html) Inferring for now that the index may not have quite enough time (i.e., by year-end) to re-rise over 120, especially with the demand recovery and shortage issues mentioned above and elsewhere. (Also: Seasonal factors may come in to play toward year-end.) April and - apparently - May 2021 numbers were more or less 'flat'/slightly declining.

May 2021 = 113.7 (April = 113.8). August 2019 was the only prior incidence of tonnage over 120.0 (120.2), dropped to 117.6 the following month, and hasn't recovered since. Had been trending steadily upward since late 2009 until the pandemic. "Tonnage, despite falling slightly over the last two months, remains well above the lows of last year," said ATA Chief Economist Bob Costello . "This is no small deal considering that truck tonnage fell significantly less than many other indicators during the depths of the pandemic in the spring of 2020. "I'm also expecting retail freight to remain robust as inventories are at historic lows. As retail stocks are rebuilt, it will boost freight. As has been the case for some time, trucking's biggest challenges are not on the demand side, but on the supply side, including difficulty finding qualified drivers." https://stockhouse.com/news/press-releases/2021/06/22/ata-truck-tonnage-index-decreased-0-7-in-may "Driver recruitment and retention remains the top priority throughout the trucking industry. Estimates suggest more than 200,000 qualified CDL holders are no longer operating due to headwinds created by the pandemic as well as increased compliance with the Drug & Alcohol Clearinghouse. Diminished driver school graduation rates, early retirements and more than 75,000 violations recorded by the clearinghouse are just some of the catalysts for the reductions in the industry’s driver pool." 
"“Overall, we’re starting to see the same general seasonal trend lines the trucking industry is used to, with applications taking a hopeful turn upward in May, which will ideally mirror 2019’s trend of an increase in applications over the summer and into the fall,”
https://www.freightwaves.com/news/driver-employment-market-may-be-improving-amid-historic-pay-increases "Last Thursday, June 10, the Port of Los Angeles became the first port in the Western Hemisphere to process 10 million container units in a 12-month period. As reported extensively by FreightWaves, it is one of many U.S. ports that is having severe congestion issues because of the veritable tidal wave of imports. As many as 25-30 ships at a time have been berthed off-shore waiting their turn to dock and unload their cargoes."
https://www.freightwaves.com/news/freightwaves-classics-port-of-los-angeles-is-the-nations-busiest Port of LA total TEU's for May was 1,012,047.85 compared to  828,662.15 in 2019. That said, 2020's total TEU of 9,213,395.95 was only down slightly from 9,337,632.40​ in 2019. https://www.portoflosangeles.org/business/statistics/container-statistics highest yoy gains look to be in the 8-9% range (ie. sept 16-17). June - Dec 2017 saw 8% increase so crossing 120 wouldn't be unprecedented. It seems there is a backlog of freight, the increase isn't statistically unlikely, so it comes down to drivers. "About 51,000 more drivers are needed to meet the demand from companies such as Amazon and Walmart that are shipping more goods across the country, according to the American Trucking Associations. The driver shortage is already leading to delayed deliveries and higher prices for goods that Americans buy. The ATA predicts that it's likely to get worse in the coming years." https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2018/05/28/america-has-a-massive-truck-driver-shortage-heres-why-few-want-an-80000-job/ Employment could pivot quickly with increased wages. And it sounds like the backlog of freight could mean demand is there. That said, port freight didn't drop as much as I would have thought and the drop from the record high was prior to the pandemic. There's also a possibility of a single month surge for a variety of reasons. It certainly isn't a guarantee but does seem possible so I'll start at 60% and work from there.

After looking at a number of factors including MOM tonnage, yearly average and YOY change along with how tonnage is impacted (or not) by things like GDP, diesel prices and considering backlogs in inventory, I find that the most compelling reason why tonnage will not exceed 120.0 before January is that there are not enough drivers available.   Over the years, tonnage per employee (employee data: https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/CES4348400001?amp%253bdata_tool=XGtable&output_view=data&include_graphs=true) is in decline.  Even while employees grew, efficiency dropped.  2020/2021 saw drops in employees + efficiency.  In a "normal" year, employment goes up throughout the year with December typically the high point.  Neither 2019 nor 2020 fit that trend.  The number of employees as of May is down from January.  I suspect we'll see some level of rebound but not as high as 120.
